summary: Pikelan day!!!! yes!!!!! its almost over for me in the uk sadly but HAPPY PIKELAN DAY guess who's voted couple of the year in...
question: Pikelan day!!!! yes!!!!! its almost over for me in the uk sadly but HAPPY PIKELAN DAY guess who's voted couple of the year in westrun? its PIKELAN. is there such a thing as couple of the year? No. Did scanlan make it up just so he could have a reason to cook for pike and congratulate her for being the best person he knows ever?!. you bet your SWEET EVERLOVING ASS HE DID. Grog wins second place. just grog.
answer:
Scanlan could absolutely make Couple of the Year a thing. He’ll just hold a ceremony, conducted by himself, bestowing a flower arrangment to Pike, hire a band. Everybody’s like ??? and he’s just oh you forgot about St Loving Day, we got couple of the year! 

He just gaslights a whole town to make a special dinner for Pike feel Really Special. 

He makes Grog a sash. It says “Grog!!!”

blog.name: kimabutch
blog.title: Revolutionary
blog.description: I'm Charlie! I'm attempting to tag "cr spoilers" until the subsequent Tuesday, but don't expect perfection. I'm into a lot of things — right now it's mostly Critical Role, but Utena still owns my heart. 22, butch lesbian, she/her. Link to asks!

summary: So I was thinking about how it was sort of inevitable that, despite their attempts at neutrality, the Mighty Nein would...
body:
So I was thinking about how it was sort of inevitable that, despite their attempts at neutrality, the Mighty Nein would eventually have to get involved in the war and make some kinds of alliances with the Empire, the Kryn, or both. People have been saying this for a long time, so it wasn’t too surprising that it happened (although, of course, the way that it happened was surprising). 

For one, the party is increasingly powerful and therefore noticeable to the warring states and both sides have a “with us or against us” kind of mentality, even for people (like Jester, Fjord, & Caduceus) who don’t come from either country. But Matt also seems to be making a point that war both hurts people you care about and offers opportunities to get what you want. If Yeza hadn’t been captured, they might have gotten pulled into the war for Caleb’s interest in Dunamancy, Beau’s involvement with the Cobalt Soul, or their desire to protect Yasha from persecution. War challenges neutrality.

And then I started thinking about how “challenging neutrality” has actually become somewhat of a reoccurring theme throughout the campaign. I don’t necessarily mean “neutral” in the sense of character alignments, so much as a desire not to get involved, to look out for oneself and one’s own goals, and to take a middle-of-the-road option when possible. 

Cause the group was initially pretty adamant that they don’t want to work for anyone: they rejected offers from both mercenary groups and the army, for example. But while many of them were similarly reluctant to have anything to do with the Knights of Requital, the Mighty Nein became key to the revolutionaries’ plan, and while they started working with the Gentleman largely because they needed protection after the Knights of Requital incident, he became an important employer. And later, even after Beau told Yussa that the Mighty Nein mostly protect each other, they decided to ally themselves with him, recognizing their need for someone powerful and knowledgeable. No adventuring group is an island, it seems. It’s really hard to survive in this world without any kind of ties to powerful people.

And the most interesting thing is that you see this same theme with many of the individual members of the Mighty Nein! The most obvious are Nott and Caleb, of course, who began the campaign caring only about each other and their respective goals, but who have come to love their friends, to the point of Nott being willing to sacrifice her life for Jester and Caleb telling them some of his deepest secrets. Despite themselves, they’ve come to care about others. Yasha is similar: she distances herself from the Mighty Nein after Molly’s death in an attempt to shield herself from grief, but (after her god fights her) finds herself opening up to Jester and Caduceus. 

But you also have Fjord’s relationship with Uk’otoa (uk’otoa, uk’otoa). He initially approached his warlock situation with a combination of curiosity and (attempted) caution: he wanted to know what had happened to him and was willing to hear this eldritch monster out for all he had to say, but never wanted to hurt anyone and relied heavily on his friends for advice about his situation. In the spirit of neutrality, he opened 2/3rds of Uk’otoa’s seals: enough to gain power but keep the monster at bay. But now, with his patron threatening him, Fjord is increasingly unable to take the middle path, and is starting to look for ways to actively counter Uk’otoa.

And Beau! Early Beau swore up and down that she was an asshole who didn’t care about other people (even after getting herself arrested to give Toya a chance to escape after the circus incident), and her early character arc, similar to Nott and Caleb, was about realizing how much she cared about others and was willing to put her life on the line for them. But it’s been even harder for Beau to admit she cares about politics beyond a vague, non-committal “fuck the man” — see, once again, her insistence to Yussa that she wasn’t aligned with anyone beyond her friends and lacked ideals. But now we’ve seen an outraged Beau tell Dairon about the Cerberus Assembly’s experiments, argue against Dairon’s racism, and promise to “serve the purpose of a better world for those who cannot defend themselves.” She’s becoming more and more interested in actually changing the world around her and bringing down the corrupt. 

Jester and Caduceus are more complicated, because both of them have non-traditional morality systems: Jester’s morality, as argued in this brilliant post by @yfere, is based on the relationships between people as opposed to the ideas of “good and evil,” while Caduceus’s morality relates more to balance and the understanding of nature. Unlike the rest of the Mighty Nein, who arguably seek neutrality to protect themselves, Jester and Caduceus’s “middle of the road” tendencies come at least partially from their faith and morality systems, and so might develop very differently. On the other hand, I think there’s something to Jester’s insistence in e56 that they don’t work for the Empire and (arguably naïve) assumption that that might in any way save them — I think she’s only starting to understand politics after so long in one place. 

Anyways, it’s just cool that this campaign has a bit of that theme going on! I guess it makes sense because the campaign so far has been so much about identity, and part of finding your identity is finding the things that you care about, that you’re willing to align yourself with, that you’ll work for or against. It’s cool.

blog.name: hazelcephalopod
blog.title: Another Side of the Mirror
blog.description:
This has mostly turned into a CR blog-thing... I tag Thursday show until around Tuesday.

Hello peoples of Tumblr! This is my blog, which I make no promise to keep up with. I'm a bisexual Autistic. Also have ADD. I like cephalopods, especially cuttlefish, and plants, and reading, and many other geeky things.

More random tidbit: feminist, somewhere in the left politically, and tired of the political landscape but still trying to care. Also a lapsed pagan, it sounds like nonsense but idk how else to describe it. More things- gluten free, and crochet, knitting, and others. Beware of my many random posts as well.

That is all for now!

Oh BTW I am bad at tagging things, trying to get better, but its a work in progress.

summary:
To my earlier post about mollymauk.
I know people still like him and all, it feels though that at least to me, nothing can be...
body:
To my earlier post about mollymauk.

I know people still like him and all, it feels though that at least to me, nothing can be done with not even just Cad but the whole group without Molly being thrown into it. I guess for me, last week with our lovely firbolg almost dying and now the theories this week of Molly possibly being reborn, I just want to scream. I’m not trying to police anyone’s fun, it’s just I think it’s more so me wanting to vent.

I’m not trying to police anyone’s fun, it’s just I think it’s more so me wanting to vent.

trail.content_raw:
To my earlier post about mollymauk.

I know people still like him and all, it feels though that at least to me, nothing can be done with not even just Cad but the whole group without Molly being thrown into it. I guess for me, last week with our lovely firbolg almost dying and now the theories this week of Molly possibly being reborn, I just want to scream. I’m not trying to police anyone’s fun, it’s just I think it’s more so me wanting to vent.
trail.content:

I’m not trying to police anyone’s fun, it’s just I think it’s more so me wanting to vent.

summary: Change the Equation - Chapter 1 - The_Disaster_Tiefling - Critical Role (Web Series) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Change the Equation - Chapter 1 - The_Disaster_Tiefling - Critical Role (Web Series) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 1/3
Fandom: Critical Role (Web Series)
Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
Warnings: Major Character Death
Characters: The Mighty Nein, Caleb Widogast, Trent Ikithon
Additional Tags: Final Battle, Truth, Loss, Death, (kind of), Self-Sacrifice, Sacrifice, Memories, Found Family, Choices, Time Travel Fix-It, Magic, Angst, Mild (not really but just being cautious) spoilers for episode 56
Summary:

It was all a lie…

Caleb was on his knees, a numbness settling over him as he stared up at Trent Ikithon as his former master lightly swung the necklace that he had believed kept him safe between his fingers as he studied Caleb. The jewel catching the light from the flames that surrounded them, cutting them off from the rest of the battlefield. Separating him from his friends, and leaving him alone, and trapped with the nightmare that he was only just starting to realise that he had never escaped.

summary: I just realized. They didn’t have a chance of talking their way out of that. Maybe if one of them had rolled a nat 20, but even...
body: I just realized. They didn’t have a chance of talking their way out of that. Maybe if one of them had rolled a nat 20, but even then it might have been iffy. That drow recognized them, and was waiting to expose them. After he exposed them, no matter how well they had lied to the queen, they would have been screwed. In fact, it may have worked in their favor. If they had successfully deceived the queen, when they were revealed they would have looked like master manipulators, and spies. Caleb probably wouldn’t have been given the chance to grab the dodecahedron, and if he had, it would have looked like a deliberate power move. Instead they just looked like idiots, and Caleb’s ploy looked like a last ditch effort to save their skins.

In fact, it may have worked in their favor. If they had successfully deceived the queen, when they were revealed they would have looked like master manipulators, and spies. Caleb probably wouldn’t have been given the chance to grab the dodecahedron, and if he had, it would have looked like a deliberate power move. Instead they just looked like idiots, and Caleb’s ploy looked like a last ditch effort to save their skins.

That drow recognized them, and was waiting to expose them. After he exposed them, no matter how well they had lied to the queen, they would have been screwed. In fact, it may have worked in their favor. If they had successfully deceived the queen, when they were revealed they would have looked like master manipulators, and spies. Caleb probably wouldn’t have been given the chance to grab the dodecahedron, and if he had, it would have looked like a deliberate power move. Instead they just looked like idiots, and Caleb’s ploy looked like a last ditch effort to save their skins.

That drow recognized them, and was waiting to expose them. After he exposed them, no matter how well they had lied to the queen, they would have been screwed. In fact, it may have worked in their favor. If they had successfully deceived the queen, when they were revealed they would have looked like master manipulators, and spies. Caleb probably wouldn’t have been given the chance to grab the dodecahedron, and if he had, it would have looked like a deliberate power move. summary: - Notes on Zemnian -  It may have been overshadowed by more momentous later developments, but can I just point out the...
body:
- Notes on Zemnian -

It may have been overshadowed by more momentous later developments, but can I just point out the overlooked gem of the last CR episode that was Caleb using the extremely reserved German polite form to address his moorbounder?

I’m petty sure it wasn’t intentional, as the subtleties of this are very difficult for native Anglophones to grasp but there is a hilarious dissonance to hearing this used between people who have any kind of friendly or familiar relationship that isn’t characterized by a steep hierarchical gradient. The idea that Caleb would speak in what amounts to either a rather stand-offish or a somewhat deferential tone to a pet is very entertaining.

One can only assume that he also uses it on Frumpkin. Fey royalty deserves respect after all.
